questions.text: Father of modern anaesthesia is _________
questions.solution:
William Morton is the father of modern anaesthesia. He was the first person to indulge into the properties of ether and investigate ether as an anesthetic. He also studied the physiology of general anesthesia.

John Snow is considered as the father of anaesthesia.
Note: John Snow is also considered the father of modern epidemiology.

questions.text: A consultant asked a junior resident to assess the ease of endotracheal intubation in a patient to be operated. The findings were similar to the schematic image given below. The resident should grade the oral opening as Mallampati class ___________
questions.solution:
Since the soft palate, the base of the uvula, and the hard palate are seen, this is graded as Mallampati class III.

The Modified Mallampati classification is used to predict difficulty in tracheal intubation. It is based on the size of the base of the tongue. During the assessment, the patient has to be seated, with the head neutral, mouth open, tongue protruding, and no phonation. In this position, the visibility of the faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate is assessed and assigned a class from I-IV. 

The initial Mallampati classification included only classes I-III. It was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class IV. In addition to classes I-IV, a fifth class also exists called class 0. In this, the epiglottis can be seen when the mouth is opened and the tongue is protruded.

Higher scores indicate poor visibility of these structures due to the presence of a large tongue. Thus, Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati classes III and IV are considered features of a difficult airway.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: A patient on clopidogrel is scheduled to undergo an elective procedure. What would be your advice regarding the drug?

choices.text: Continue but omit the morning dose

questions.solution:
Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet drug and is stopped 1 week prior to surgery to avoid the risk of increased surgical bleeding.

Antiplatelets Waiting period
Ticlopidine 10 days
Clopidogrel 5-7 days
Abciximab 48 hr
Eptifibatide 8 hr
 

Related Pearl: Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery

Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery:

Drug Duration before discontinuation

 Discontinue on the day of surgery

Discontinue on the day of surgery

Oral hypoglycemic agents (except SGLT-2 inhibitors)

Discontinue on the day of surgery

Discontinue 24 hours before elective surgery and 72 hours before intermediate to high risk surgery

Discontinue 24 hours before the day of surgery

 Discontinue 48 hours before the day of surgery

questions.text: Preoperative fasting recommendation is _________

choices.text: 2 hours for breast milk in infants

questions.solution:
Preoperative fasting recommendation is 2 hours for liquids in adults.

Recommended Preoperative Fasting period:

  • For neonates and infants:
    • 2 hours for clear fluids
    • 4 hours for breast milk
    • 6 hours for solids and infant formula
  • For all above 1 year of age:
    • 2 hours for clear fluids
    • 6 hours for a light meal
    • 8 hours if the meal contains fried, fatty food

Preoperative fasting is intended to reduce the risk of pulmonary aspiration.

questions.text: You are a junior resident conducting research on the efficacy of different methods to monitor the depth of anaesthesia. Which of the following methods will be not be considered for evaluation in your research?
questions.solution:
Capnography is not considered as it cannot be used to monitor the depth of anaesthesia.

Capnography is a quantitative measure of end-tidal carbon dioxide that is used to assess ventilation in the perioperative period and confirm the correct placement of an endotracheal tube.

Monitors used to assess the depth of anaesthesia: 

  1. Electroencephalography (EEG)
  2. Bispectral index (BIS)
  3. Entropy
  4. Evoked responses (EP) - Motor EP, sensory EP (Auditory, visual, brain stem evoked potential)
  5. Patient state index
  6. Narcotrend.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions does this capnographic waveform appear?
questions.solution:
The image given in the question shows a capnograph with some carbon dioxide detected initially followed by absence of carbon dioxide- this is typical of esophageal intubation.

Swallowed air in the stomach would cause the initial detection of CO2 which is soon washed out and the ETCO2 comes to zero.

Option A: Malignant hyperthermia – progressive rise in CO2. 

Option C: Rebreathing of CO2 - elevated inspiratory baseline.

Option D: Tracheal intubation - normal capnograph.

questions.text: Size of the laryngeal mask airway that can be used in a child weighing 15 kgs is _________
questions.solution:
Size 2 laryngeal mask airway can be used in a child weighing 15 kgs.

Laryngeal mask airway is a supraglottic airway device which is placed in the hypopharynx and protects the larynx from laryngeal secretions. The largest possible size is chosen so as to ensure an airtight seal.

Different sizes of the laryngeal mask airway

questions.text: The following device is most suitable for?
questions.solution:
The image given shows Microlaryngeal tube. It has smaller internal diameters and longer length which makes them useful for laryngeal surgeries.

Other endotracheal tubes:

Armored or reinforced tubes: They are flexible, spiral wound tubes which are reinforced with an embedded coil so as to minimize kinking. They are useful in head and neck surgeries and when the patient is in prone position.

Ring-adair-elwin type of endotracheal tube.It is preferable for nasal and ophthalmic surgeries because it has a preformed right-angle bend at the level of the teeth so that it doesn’t disrupt the surgical field.

Double-lumen endotracheal tubes –to facilitate lung isolation and one-lung ventilation.

Endotracheal tubes equipped with bronchial blockers – which can also facilitate lung isolation and one-lung ventilation.

Metal tubes for laser airway surgery to reduce fire hazards.

questions.text: Ultra short acting non depolarising muscle relaxant is ________
questions.solution:
Gantacurium is ultra short acting (<10minutes) non depolarising muscle relaxant.

Gantacurium: It has two pathways of inactivation.

  1. Slower ester hydrolysis
  2. Adduction of cysteine to create a new compound that can no longer bind to the acetylcholine receptor of the neuromuscular junction. Therefore, it has ultrashort duration of action and fast recovery.

Mivacurium is short acting non depolarising muscle relaxant. (10-20mins)

Atracurium is intermediate acting non depolarising muscle relaxant. (20-50mins)

Suxamethonium is the shortest acting depolarising muscle relaxant.

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium
  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)
    • Atracurium
    • Cisatracurium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)
    • Pancuronium
    • Doxacurium
    • Pipecuronium

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects would you not expect while using succinylcholine as a muscle relaxant for a surgery being done under general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Succinylcholine increases intragastric pressure. This is likely due to fasciculations of the abdominal skeletal muscle.

Related Pearl: Side effects of succinyl choline

The following are the side effects of succinyl choline:

  • Cardiovascular effects:
    • Sinus bradycardia
    • Junctional rhythms
    • Ventricular dysrhythmias
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Myalgia
  • Masseter spasm: Succinyl choline can trigger malignant hyperthermia
  • Increased intracranial pressure: Succinylcholine may lead to an activation of the EEG and slight increases in CBF and ICP in some patients.
  • Increased intraocular pressure
  • Increased intragastric pressure

questions.text: Dibucaine number < 30 indicates ______
questions.solution:
Dibucaine number < 30 indicates prolonged succinylcholine block.

Dibucaine inhibits the typical pseudocholinesterase enzyme approximately 80% and the atypical enzyme approximately 20%. Dibucaine number refers to the percentage of inhibition of pseudocholinesterase activity.

A patient with normal pseudocholinesterase has a dibucaine number of 80, whereas a homozygote for atypical enzyme will have a dibucaine number of 20.

Hence, at a low dibucaine number(<30), there will be low quantity of typical pseudocholinesterase and high quantity of atypical pseudocholinesterase.

Succinylcholine-induced neuromuscular blockade can be significantly prolonged if a patient has an abnormal genetic variant of pseudocholinesterase. Therefore there is a prolonged succinyl choline and mivacurium block in case of low dibucaine number.

Related Pearl: Dibucaine number

  • High dibucaine number (80) means the high quantity of normal and low quantity of atypical pseudocholinesterase: normal response to succinylcholine and mivacurium.
  • Low dibucaine number (<30) means the low quantity of normal and high quantity of atypical pseudocholinesterase: prolonged succinylcholine and mivacurium block.

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement concerning rapacuronium?

choices.text: Rapid onset and short duration of action

questions.solution:
Rapacuronium is a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant that has a very high incidence of bronchospasm (>9%) and so it is contraindicated in asthmatics.

It has been withdrawn from the market due to this effect.

Rapacuronium has a rapid onset and short duration of action and minimal cardiovascular side effects.

questions.text: On witnessing a cardiac arrest, what is the first thing you would do?
questions.solution:
The first thing that needs to be done on witnessing a cardiac arrest is to verify the scene safety.

On ensuring that the scene is safe, the victim is checked for responsiveness. If unresponsive, call for help and then check for breathing and pulse simultaneously taking not more than 10 seconds.

If there is no breathing and no pulse, immediate chest compression and rescue breaths are started at a ratio of 30:2.

If there is a pulse, but no breathing, give one rescue breath every 5-6 seconds or about 10-12 breaths/min.

When an automated external defibrillator arrives, the rhythm is checked; if shockable, one shock is administered and CPR is resumed immediately.

If not shockable, then CPR is resumed immediately.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the casualty after having suddenly collapsed while playing. Pulse is not recordable and CPR is started. After 2 minutes of CPR, the monitor shows ventricular fibrillation rhythm. What is the energy to be set for defibrillation?
questions.solution:
In a pediatric cardiac arrest, the initial energy for defibrillation is set at 2 J/kg for both monophasic and biphasic waveforms. It is increased to 4 J/kg if a second shock is required.

If a pediatric defibrillator is not available, then an adult defibrillator can be used.

In children the most common cause of cardiac arrest is asphyxia. However, a sudden witnessed collapse in a child is usually due to ventricular fibrillation.

For adult defibrillation, the energy that must be applied is

  • Monophasic defibrillator– 360 J
  • Biphasic defibrillator- 120-200 J (manufacturer recommended)

questions.text: What is the maximum oxygen concentration delivered by a venturi mask?
questions.solution:
Venturi mask is a high-flow, fixed-performance oxygen delivery system and the highest oxygen concentration (FiO2) delivered is 60% at a flow rate of 15 L/min.

It is available in different colors, with the green valve venturi mask providing 60% FiO2. 

This is useful with patients who require greater FiO2 such as COPD patients, where it is important to provide controlled oxygenation.

Colour of Venturi valve FiO2 (%) Flow rate 
(L/min)
Blue 24  2
White 28  4
Orange 31  6
Yellow 35  8
Red 40  10
Green 60  15

questions.text: The most potent inhaled anaesthetic in use is _____________
questions.solution:
Halothane (MAC - 0.75) is the most potent anaesthetic currently in use. Methoxyflurane with MAC of 0.2 was the most potent inhaled anaesthetic. However, it is no longer in use.

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) of an inhaled anesthetic is the lowest concentration which is required to prevent movement in response to a defined noxious stimulus in 50% of subjects. It is a measure of potency of the inhalational anesthetics. So, lower the MAC value, lower is the concentration of anesthetic drug required which would imply the drug is more potent.

Example:

  • Nitrous oxide with a MAC value of 104 is the least potent inhaled anesthetic
  • Methoxy flurane – MAC- 0.2 (most potent)
  • Desflurane: 6.0 (least potent among used)
  • Sevoflurane– 2.05
  • Isoflurane – 1.28
  • Halothane – 0.75 (most potent among used)

questions.text: Second gas effect is related to _____________
questions.solution:
Second gas effect is related to concentration effect. It is seen when nitrous oxide is given in high concentration (66%). It refers to the principle that the concentration of inspired anesthetic gas influences:

  • the alveolar concentration that may be attained
  • the rate at which that concentration may be attained.

Second Gas Effect is seen when nitrous oxide is administered with another inhaled anesthetic. 

Uptake of nitrous oxide from the alveoli into the blood results in a gradient which draws in more nitrous oxide from the anesthetic machine (augmented inflow). If another gas is simultaneously administered, nitrous oxide enhances the uptake of that gas as well. 

Second gas effect is seen with nitrous oxide, not ether or oxygen.

Diffusion hypoxia: It occurs during recovery from nitrous oxide anesthesia when nitrous oxide is suddenly cut off. Nitrous oxide diffuses from the blood to the alveoli and replaces the oxygen which reduces alveolar O2 concentration, resulting in relative hypoxemia.

questions.text: Which of the following inhalational agents is suitable for neurosurgery?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, isoflurane is best suited for neurosurgery.

All of the inhalational anesthetics are cerebral vasodilators. The order of vasodilating potency is:

halothane > enflurane > desflurane > isoflurane > sevoflurane. 

Note: Due to its lesser vasodilating property, sevoflurane is preferred to isoflurane for neurosurgery.

Related Pearl: Inhalational anaesthetic agents

Inhalational agent of choice: 

Indication Anesthetic gas
1. Induction  Sevoflurane
2. Daycare surgery Sevflurane>Desflurane
3. Elderly  Desflurane
4. Cardiac surgery Isoflurane
5. Renal disease Desflurane
6. Liver disease  Sevoflurane > Desflurane 
7. Neurosurgery    Sevoflurane>Isoflurane
8. Asthmatics Sevoflurane
9. Obese patients Desflurane

 

Feature Drug
Most potent       Methoxyflurane > Halothane 
Least potent      Nitrous oxide > Desflurane 
Most epileptogenic   Enflurane
Most nephrotoxic Methoxyflurane 
Most hepatotoxic Halothane

questions.text: Fulminant hepatic necrosis  is least common with which of the following inhalational anaesthetics?
questions.solution:
Fulminant hepatic necrosis is least common with sevoflurane. Unlike other volatile anesthetics, sevoflurane is oxidized to form hexafluoroisopropanol which is stable and does not covalently bind to proteins and hence does not cause hepatic injury. 

Sevoflurane is the agent of choice in a patient with a prior history of halothane hepatitis.

Halothane hepatitis is due to antibodies against highly reactive trifluoroacetyl chloride which is a metabolite of halothane.

Like Halothane, Enflurane, Desflurane and Isoflurane also undergo extensive metabolism to produce highly reactive intermediates that can covalently modify hepatic proteins which can cause severe hepatitis.

questions.text: Which of the following inhalational agents produces a nephrotoxic substance called compound A?
questions.solution:
Sevoflurane reacts with strong bases like sodium hydroxide and potassium hydroxide present in soda-lime and baralyme leading to the formation of a haloalkene (fluoromethyl-2,2-difluoro-1-[trifluoromethyl] vinyl ether) known as compound A.

Compound A has the potential to cause proximal tubular necrosis. 

Risk factors for increased compound A production:

  • Prolonged duration of anesthesia
  • High concentration of sevoflurane
  • Low flow techniques
  • Dry baralyme

A fresh gas flow of at least 2L/ min can prevent the generation of compound A

Amsorb is a CO2 absorbent that is more inert than soda-lime and baralyme and so associated with lesser degradation of sevoflurane and less compound A production.

questions.text: Which of the following barbiturates is not completely eliminated by the liver?
questions.solution:
Phenobarbitone is not completely eliminated by the liver. 25% to 50% of the drug is excreted by the kidneys in an unchanged form.

All barbiturates (thiopentone, thiamylal, methohexital) other than phenobarbitone are completely eliminated by the liver.

questions.text: A junior resident accidentally administered thiopentone intra-arterial to a patient. Management should involve all of the following except ___________
questions.solution:
The injection needle should not be removed in case of intraarterial thiopentone injection.

Treatment for intraarterial thiopentone injection:

  • If thiopentone is administered intra-arterially stop the injection immediately and further injection of the drug should not be done.
  • Injection needle should not be removed. This is done because saline can be administered via the same needle to dilute the drug.
  • Administer heparin to prevent thrombosis.
  • Brachial plexus block or stellate ganglion block

questions.text: Propofol infusion syndrome is seen when propofol infusion is __________
questions.solution:
Propofol infusion syndrome is seen when propofol infusion is >4mg/kg/hour for 48hours.

Propofol infusion syndrome:

  • It is a rare but lethal syndrome seen when the propofol infusion is greater than 4 mg/kg/ hour for 48 hours or longer. This syndrome is common in children and critically ill adults.
  • Clinical features include
    • acute refractory bradycardia leading to asystole,
    • metabolic acidosis (base deficit >10 mmol/L),
    • rhabdomyolysis,
    • hyperlipidemia,
    • enlarged or fatty liver

questions.text: A child was administered an anesthetic for fracture reduction in the ER. He could open his eyes, was blabbering and breathing spontaneously but did not feel any pain. Which anesthetic agent was administered?
questions.solution:
The given features suggest dissociative anaesthesia, which is a characteristic feature of ketamine.

Ketamine produces dissociative anesthesia which is characterized by a state wherein the patient is conscious (eg., eye opening, swallowing, muscle contracture) but unable to process or respond to sensory input.

Ketamine functionally “dissociates” the thalamus (which relays sensory impulses from the reticular activating system to the cerebral cortex) from the limbic cortex (which is involved with the awareness of sensation). It acts as an antagonist at the phencyclidine site of the NMDA receptor.

questions.text: True about the circuit given below is _________

choices.text: Also called Jackson Rees modification circuit

questions.solution:
The circuit given in the image is Mapleson A or Magill circuit. It has a low fresh gas flow rate requirement of 1 x minute ventilation to prevent rebreathing of carbon dioxide. Hence, it is considered the best for spontaneous ventilation.

In Mapleson circuits D, E, and F, the amount of fresh gas flow required is 2.5 times a minute ventilation and in mapleson circuits B and C, it is much higher.

Mapleson circuit A is not very useful in controlled ventilation because minute ventilation as high as 20 L/minute (fresh gas flow rate should be greater than 3 times minute ventilation) is needed to prevent rebreathing. Mapleson circuit D is used for controlled ventilation.

 

Related Pearl: Mapleson Classification

Spontaneous ventilation  Controlled ventilation

B - 2-3× (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
C Water’s to and fro 2-3 × (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
D Bain circuit 2-3 × (MV) 1-2 × (MV)
E Ayre’s t-piece 2-3 × (MV) 3 × (MV)

Note:

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in spontaneous ventilation is  A > DFE > CB (A Dog Can Bite - Usually a spontaneous event)

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is DFE > BC > A (Dead Babies can't assist - controlled)

questions.text: Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with less than 7% CO2 will have pin index ___________
questions.solution:
Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with less than 7% CO2 will have pin index 2, 6.

Related Pearl: Pin index safety system (PISS):

Note:

  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with more than 7% CO2: 1,6
  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with less than 7% CO2: 2,6

questions.text: Most common complication of the block shown in the image below is ___________
questions.solution:
The image depicts interscalene block which is performed between the anterior and middle scalene muscles in the interscalene groove at the level of C6. Diaphragmatic paresis is the most common complication seen in interscalene block (seen in 100%). It is due to ipsilateral phrenic nerve blockade.

This can result in dyspnea, hypoxia, and hypercapnea especially if the patient has compromised lung function or pre existing contralateral phrenic nerve paralysis. It can be minimized by performing ultrasound guided blocks, using smaller volumes of local anaesthetic and blocking the brachial plexus at a lower level in the neck.

Other complications of interscalene block are:

  • Horners syndrome – ptosis, myosis, anhydrosis. Due to involvement of the sympathetic nerves to the cervicothoracic ganglion
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
  • Vagus nerve involvement
  • Pneumothorax
  • Bezold Jarisch reflex
  • Accidental vertebral artery injection (immediate seizure is seen)
  • Accidental spinal or epidural injection

questions.text: A child presents with a dislocated fracture of the first metacarpal. What is the preferred regional anaesthesia technique for the surgery?
questions.solution:
The axillary block is the most preferred approach to the brachial plexus in pediatric patients for surgeries of the elbow, forearm, and hand.

It is a relatively easy and safe procedure. Complications include systemic toxicity due to accidental intraarterial injection and permanent nerve injury from the intraneural injection.

questions.text: Which receptor mediates supraspinal analgesia produced by opioids?
questions.solution:
µ, k and δ receptors mediate both supraspinal and spinal analgesia produced by opioids.

  • Supraspinal analgesia is predominantly mediated by µ1 receptor and spinal analgesia by k receptor.
  • μ-receptor agonists usually produce analgesia, whereas κ-receptor agonists may produce analgesia or antianalgesia.
  • Within the spinal cord, opioids act on the opioid receptors in substantia gelatinosa and inhibit the release of substance P from the sensory neurons.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding tramadol?
questions.solution:
Tramadol is contraindicated in epileptics.

Tramadol is epileptogenic and can cause seizures in predisposed individuals and in those taking medications like monoamine oxidase inhibitors and neuroleptic drugs.

It is a synthetic analogue of codeine and a weak opioid agonist with 1/6000 affinity for µ receptors as that of morphine.

Apart from opioid action, it also inhibits the reuptake of 5HT and NE. Due to non-opioid receptor-mediated actions, it produces less respiratory depression and less constipation.

questions.text: Opioid with highest water partition coefficient is ________
questions.solution:
Sufentanil has the highest water partition coefficient and hence is the most potent opioid.

Fentanyl is 100 times more potent and sufentanil is 1000 times more potent than morphine.

 

Octanol/ water partition coefficients of opioids

 

  • Octanol/water partition coefficient is a measure of the potency of a compound and the ability to traverse lipid membranes.
    • Morphine – 1.4
    • Remifentanil – 17.3
    • Alfentanil -145
    • Fentanyl – 813
    • Sufentanil-1778
  • As can be seen, sufentanil has the highest octanol/water partition coefficient making it the most potent opioid.

questions.text:
A patient has presented to your OPD with a sebaceous cyst on the scalp. You plan to excise it. Before making the first incision, you inject lidocaine around it. Which of the following effects does this drug have?
  1. Inhibition of Na channel
  2. Potentiation of K channel
  3. Interaction with NMDA receptors
  4. Inhibition of Ca channel
  5. Interference with oxidative phosphorylation
questions.solution:
Local anesthetics inhibit potassium channels. 

The effects of local anesthetics include:

  • Inhibition of voltage-gated Na channels
  • Blockade of potassium and calcium channels
  • Transient receptor potential vanilloid 1 (TRPV1)
  • Interaction with cholinergic or N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptors
  • Interference with cellular metabolic processes (eg, oxidative phosphorylation, free fatty acid utilization)

However, the main action of local anesthetics is mediated by inhibition of voltage-gated Na channels.

questions.text: Methaemoglobinaemia is a side effect of ___________
questions.solution:
Both prilocaine and benzocaine can cause methaemoglobinaemia.

Prilocaine is the only local anesthetic that is metabolized to o -toluidine, which converts hemoglobin to methemoglobin producing methemoglobinemia. This is usually significant with doses of prilocaine as large as 600mg.

Benzocaine and cetacaine used as topical local anesthetic sprays can also cause dangerous Methemoglobinemia.

Treatment of medically important methemoglobinemia includes intravenous methylene blue (1–2 mg/kg of a 1% solution over 5 min). Methylene blue acts by reducing methemoglobin (Fe 3+ ) to hemoglobin (Fe 2+).

questions.text: When asked to administer a combination of lignocaine and epinephrine for a minor procedure under local anesthesia, what concentration of epinephrine will you use?
questions.solution:
Epinephrine is used along with local anesthetics at a concentration of 5 μg/mL or 1:200,000. At this dose, epinephrine provides adequate vasoconstriction.

Advantages of vasoconstrictors:

  • Increased duration of action
  • Improved depth of anesthesia
  • Decreased local anesthetic toxicity
  • As a marker for inadvertent intravascular injection

questions.text: A patient presents with a foreign body in the right cornea. Which would be the topical anesthetic of choice to remove it?
questions.solution:
Tetracaine is the topical anesthesia of choice for the removal of foreign bodies from the cornea.

Topical anesthetics used in ophthalmology include: 

  • Tetracaine
  • Proparacaine eye drops
  • Lidocaine gel
  • Intranasal cocaine

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is observed to have difficulty in breathing along with bluish discolouration of his lips and fingers while playing. It improves on adopting a knee-chest position. Which is the ideal induction agent of choice used for surgical correction of the condition suffered by this patient?
questions.solution:
Ketamine is the induction agent of choice in this patient who is likely suffering from tetralogy of Fallot because it maintains or increases systemic vascular resistance and increases cardiac output.

Tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by sub pulmonic stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, ventricular septal defect and overriding of the aorta. This results in a right to left shunt through the ventricular septal defect and consequent cyanosis.

The commonest symptoms are dyspnea on exertion and exercise intolerance and develop blue skin (cyanosis) when agitated and are known as tet spells. The patients assume a sitting posture (squatting) or knee-chest position as soon as they get dyspneic, which leads to temporary symptomatic relief.

Ketamine does not aggravate the right to left shunt seen in such cases. It also does not increase pulmonary vascular resistance in children as compared to adults and is hence safe to administer in children.

Ketamine is the agent of choice in all cyanotic congenital heart diseases.

questions.text: Regional anaesthesia is preferred over general anaesthesia in transurethral resection of prostate because ________

choices.text: Less chance of masking TURP syndrome

questions.solution:
All the above statements are true.

Regional anesthesia is preferred over general anesthesia in TURP because:

  • Less likely to mask the symptoms of TURP syndrome: It helps to assess patients mental status. Alteration in mental status is an early sign of excess irrigation fluid absorption and TURP syndrome. Acute hyponatremia from TURP syndrome may delay or prevent emergence from general anesthesia.
  • Lesser amount of operative blood loss.
  • Lesser risk of deep vein thrombosis.
  • Less likely to mask symptoms of bladder perforation.
  • Decreased need for analgesics in the immediate post –operative period.

Spinal anesthesia is preferred over epidural anesthesia because:

  • Easier to perform in elderly patients.
  • Duration of surgery is not usually long.
  • Epidural anesthesia may incompletely block the sacral nerve roots which can be avoided with spinal anesthesia.

Caudal anesthesia may be used in high-risk patients undergoing laser prostatectomy as it provides the advantage of hemodynamic stability.

questions.text: Which of the following is a complication of retrobulbar block?
questions.solution:
Both subconjunctival haemorrhage and proptosis are complications of retrobulbar anaesthesia.

Retrobulbar block is a regional anesthesia technique used in ophthalmic surgery which involves the injection of a local anesthetic into the extraocular muscle cone. The needle penetrates the lower lid at the junction of lateral one third and medial two third of the orbit.

Related Pearl: Complications and contraindications of retrobulbar block

Complications:

  • Retrobulbar hemorrhage (most common complication)
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhage
  • Proptosis
  • Perforation of the globe
  • Optic nerve atrophy
  • Oculocardiac reflex
  • Accidental intravascular injection of the local anesthetic
  • Trigeminal nerve block
  • Respiratory arrest
  • Acute neurogenic pulmonary edema (rarely)

Contraindications:

  • Bleeding disorders (because of the risk of retrobulbar hemorrhage)
  • High myopia (if the axial length is greater than 25 mm, then sclera would be thin which could increase the risk of globe perforation)
  • Open eye injury or penetrating eye injury: injection of local anesthetic behind the globe could increase the intraocular pressure which could lead to extrusion of the orbital contents.

questions.text: Which of the following agents used in children has not been associated with a potential risk of drug-induced apoptosis?
questions.solution:
Opioids like fentanyl have not been associated with the phenomenon of drug-induced apoptosis. 

Drugs that have not been associated with apoptosis:

  • Dexmedetomidine
  • Opioids
  • Xenon

Drugs that have been associated with apoptosis in laboratory animals:

  • Nitrous oxide
  • Ketamine
  • Propofol
  • Etomidate
  • Barbiturates
  • Benzodiazepines
  • Chloral hydrate
  • Ethanol

The potential risks for apoptosis in children are seen especially in ages less than 3 years which is the period of rapid brain growth. But human studies regarding the potential for drug-induced apoptosis and its consequences like neurocognitive dysfunction are insufficient.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of perioperative vision loss?
questions.solution:
Ischemic optic neuropathy is the most common cause of perioperative vision loss.

It is usually seen after spine surgeries in the prone position, radical neck dissections and following cardiopulmonary bypass.

Symptoms: Reduced visual acuity, rarely complete blindness; usually presents on awakening from anesthesia.

Preoperative risk factors: 

  • Diabetes, hypertension
  • Smoking
  • Coronary artery disease.

Intraoperative risk factors: 

  • Anaemia
  • Hypotension
  • Prone position
  • Prolonged duration of surgery

questions.text: All of the following statements about post anaesthetic shivering are true except ___________

choices.text: Peri operative hypothermia is the major cause
Intensity is more with spinal than epidural anaesthesia

questions.solution:
Intensity of shivering is more with epidural than spinal anaesthesia. This is because spinal anaesthesia causes more profound motor block and consequently, inability to shiver.

Post anaesthetic shivering:

  • Peri operative hypothermia is the major cause of post anaesthetic shivering.
  • The incidence of post-anesthetic shivering is around 40%.
  • It can increase oxygen consumption, catecholamine release, cardiac output, heart rate and blood pressure which can aggravate cardiovascular mortality especially in elderly patients.
  • The most efficient way to reduce post-anesthetic shivering is to prevent hypothermia by avoiding cold epidural and intravenous fluids.
  • Meperidine is the most effective treatment for post-anesthetic shivering.
  • Other drugs:
    • Clonidine
    • Ketanserin
    • Tramadol
    • Physostigmine
    • Nefopam
    • Dexmedetomidine
    • Magnesium sulfate

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is posted for inguinal hernia surgery. In order to perform a fast-track surgical procedure, the anesthetic technique of choice is:
questions.solution:
Infiltration anesthesia is ideal to perform inguinal hernia repair as a fast-track procedure.

It has a lesser incidence of complications than regional or general anesthesia. Other anesthetic techniques for hernia repair include intercostal block and ilioinguinal nerve block.

Ambulatory/Outpatient anesthesia employs the use of fast - Track surgical techniques to provide adequate surgical anesthesia and minimize post-operative complications in order to reduce the duration of hospital stay.

Disadvantage of infiltration anesthesia - Short duration of anesthesia even when long-acting local anesthetics like bupivacaine are used. Extended- duration local anesthesia can be produced by encapsulating bupivacaine into a biodegradable carrier.

Regional anesthesia is contraindicated in patients with bleeding disorders, those on anticoagulants and with local infections.

Spinal anesthesia has the disadvantage over epidural anesthesia of delayed recovery due to profound motor blockade. Spinal opioids like fentanyl or sufentanil are added to prolong postoperative analgesia and minimize motor block without delaying recovery. But the adverse effects of spinal opioids like nausea, pruritus and postoperative urinary retention are additive.

questions.text: After neuraxial block, patient was unable to raise extended leg, but was able to move knees or feet. Motor block in this patient as per modified bromage scale is ________
questions.solution:
Inability to raise extended leg but being able to move knees and feet, after a neuraxial block is graded as stage 1 as per modified bromage scale.

Modified bromage scale is the most common method used for assessment of motor block following neuraxial anaesthesia. The disadvantage is it represents only lumbosacral motor fibers.

Related Pearl: Modified Bromage scale

0: No motor block

1: Inability to raise the extended leg; Able to move knees and feet

2: Inability to raise the extended leg and move knee; Able to move feet

3: Complete block of motor limb

questions.text: A patient is set to undergo cesarean section under subarachnoid block. Upto which dermatome must the anaesthetist ensure adequate anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
For a cesarean section, the sensory block should be achieved up to T4 dermatomal level (motor T6), as the pain-sensitive peritoneum innervation starts from T4 level.

The risk of high spinal and severe hypotension is higher because the block has to reach T4. Hence, consider prehydration with 20 ml/kg, proper positioning, and keeping phenylephrine or ephedrine on hand.

Dermatomal Level required for Various Common Surgical Procedures:

  • T4 - Upper abdominal surgery
  • T10 - Transurethral resection of prostate
  • T10 - Hip surgery
  • L2 - Foot and ankle surgery

questions.text: A patient is complaining of severe headache following hernia surgery under spinal anesthesia. The headache is occipital in location which worsens on standing and is relieved by lying flat. All of the following needles can be used to perform spinal anesthesia to reduce the incidence of the above condition except
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient complained of headache in the occiput which worsens on standing and is relieved by lying flat following spinal anesthesia is suggestive of post-dural puncture headache. Quincke needle increases the risk of post-dural puncture headache.

The Quincke needle is a cutting needle with an end injection. Whitacre and Tuohy are Pencil-point needles (blunt needles) which reduce the incidence of post–dural puncture headaches.

Types of needles based on tip shapes:

  •  Dura cutting needles:
    • Quincke-babcock needle
    • Pitkin needle
  • Pencil point needles (blunt):
    • Whitacre
    • Sprotte - side-injection needle with a long opening
    • Tuohy - most commonly used needle for epidural anesthesia
    • Greene

PDPH can occur after spinal or epidural anesthesia due to loss of CSF through the dura which causes traction on the pain-sensitive intracranial structures. It may also occur due to compensatory, painful intracranial vasodilation to offset the reduction in intracranial pressure. Most cases occur within 72 hours of dural puncture. 

The headache worsens with the standing or seated position and is relieved by lying in the supine position. It is typically frontal or occipital in distribution and the associated symptoms include nausea, neck stiffness, low back pain, vertigo, vision changes, and auditory disturbances. 

Diagnosis is based on typical history and imaging is only rarely performed to exclude other diagnoses.

Management of PDPH: Most of the headaches resolve spontaneously within 7 days. Conservative management includes

  • Supine positioning
  • Hydration
  • Caffeine
  • Oral analgesics
  • Sumatriptan
  • An epidural blood patch is the definitive management.
    • It is ideally performed 24 hours after dural puncture and the development of classic symptoms.
    • 15-20 mL of autologous blood is injected into the epidural space at the same or one interspace below the level of the dural puncture.
    • It acts by stopping the CSF leak by either mass effect or coagulation.
    • Most patients will respond to a single blood patch, and 90% of initial nonresponders will obtain relief from a second injection (1 to 2 days after the first).
    • A prophylactic epidural patch is not recommended.

Related Pearl: PDPH- Post-Dural Puncture Headache

  • May follow lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, wet epidural tap (in which epidural needle pierced dura).
  • Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.
  • Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.
  • Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.
  • Prevention by thinner needle

Management:

  • Supine position
  • IV fluids
  • Caffeine and analgesia
  • Epidural blood patch

Related Pearl: Factors That Can Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Age: Younger, more frequent
  • Sex: Females > males
  • Needle size: Larger > smaller
  • Needle bevel: Less when the needle bevel is placed in the long axis of the neuraxis Orienting a needle bevel parallel with the axis of the spine, such that the longitudinal fibers of the dura would more likely be separated than cut, results in a lower incidence of postspinal puncture headache
  • Pregnancy: More when pregnant
  • Dural punctures: More with multiple punctures

Factors That Do Not Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Insertion and use of catheters for continuous spinal anesthesia
  • Timing of ambulation

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy with CTEV is undergoing corrective treatment. He is scheduled for a posteromedial soft tissue release procedure. You see the anaesthesia resident mark out the points shown in the image on his back. In what anaesthetic procedure are these landmarks used?
questions.solution:
The landmarks depicted in the image are in reference to caudal anaesthesia. It is a common regional technique in paediatrics for procedures below the diaphragm, including urogenital, rectal, inguinal, and lower extremity surgery. 

Caudal anaesthesia involves deposition of local anaesthetic in the caudal epidural space, accessed through the sacral hiatus. Sacral hiatus is formed by the unfused S4 and S5 laminae and is covered by the sacrococcygeal ligament.

The lines joining the posterior superior iliac spines and sacral hiatus make an equilateral triangle. The sacral hiatus is felt as a groove or notch above the coccyx and between two bony prominences, the sacral cornua.

It is better appreciated in children than in adults and hence it is a common regional technique among pediatric patients.

questions.text: A patient had bilateral pain in buttocks radiating to legs within 24 hours after undergoing surgery under spinal anaesthesia. There is no other neurological abnormality. This is most likely due to which of the following anaesthetic?
questions.solution:
Bilateral pain in buttocks radiating to legs within 24 hours after undergoing surgery under spinal anaesthesia, is suggestive of transient neurological symptoms which is seen in case of Lidocaine and mepivacaine. It is less frequent with bupivacaine.

Transient neurological symptoms:

  • It is commonly associated with spinal lidocaine (not commonly associated with epidural lidocaine)
  • The phenomenon is related to the concentration of lidocaine, the addition of dextrose or epinephrine, or solution osmolarity.
  • Symptoms are usually characterized by bilateral or unilateral pain in the buttocks radiating to the legs or, less commonly, isolated buttock or leg pain. Symptoms occur within 24 hours of the resolution of an otherwise uneventful spinal anesthetic and are not associated with any neurologic deficits or laboratory abnormalities.
  • TNS occurs more commonly in patients who are placed in the lithotomy position for surgery.
  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are the first line of treatment, but pain can be severe and may even require opioids.

questions.text: Anaphylactic reactions are least common with __________
questions.solution:
Anaphylactic reactions are least common (<0.06%) with hydroxyethyl starch as it is non antigenic.

  • The incidence of anaphylaxis and anaphylactoid reactions is maximum with gelatin (<0.35%).
  • The occurrence of anaphylaxis following dextran is intermediate (0.28%). This can be minimized by pretreatment with a hapten inhibitor dextran1.
  • Albumin also results in allergic reactions.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida is screaming in pain while being wheeled into the labour room at 2 am. On examination, her cervix is well-effaced and is 4 cm dilated. What is the preferred anaesthetic technique to ensure this patient has a painless labour?
questions.solution:
Lumbar epidural is the most commonly used technique to produce labour analgesia because it can provide analgesia during the first stage of labour and also provide anaesthesia during vaginal delivery or cesarean section if necessary.

For adequate pain relief, the sensory block of T10-L1 is required during the first stage of labour and S2-S4 is required during the second stage. The epidural catheter placed at L3-L4 or L4-L5 interspace sufficiently provides T10–S5 neural blockade.

Option A: Pudendal nerve block is given in the second stage of labor just before delivery of the baby to provide analgesia to the vulva and anus​. However, it has no effect on the pain of contractions. It is also given before repair of episiotomy or perineal lacerations.

Option B: Spinal anaesthesia for labour analgesia has the advantage of a rapid and reliable onset of the neural blockade, and it is technically easier to administer compared to epidural analgesia. However, repeated intrathecal injections may be required for a prolonged labour, thus increasing the risk of post-dural puncture headache.

Option C: Caudal epidural is largely abandoned to provide pain relief in obstetrics. It requires large volumes of a local anaesthetic to anaesthetize upper lumbar and lower thoracic dermatomes to provide adequate labour analgesia. Though rare, accidental puncture of the fetus is a possibility.

questions.text: In which of the following situations can bag and mask ventilation be performed?

choices.text: Obese individual with a difficult airway
Emergency laparotomy requiring rapid sequence induction
Diaphragmatic hernia following blunt trauma to chest

questions.solution:
Bag and mask ventilation can be performed in patients with difficult airway.

Bag and mask ventilation serves as a rescue technique to provide oxygenation and ventilation in patients with difficult airway until tracheal intubation is achieved.


Contraindications of bag and mask ventilation: 

Patients at greater risk of aspiration such as patients with diaphragmatic hernia and those undergoing rapid sequence induction and intubation. This is because air can enter the stomach leading to raised intragastric pressure which increases the risk of aspiration.

Mask ventilation should also be performed with caution in patients with severe facial trauma and in patients in whom head and neck manipulation must be avoided (e.g., those with an unstable cervical spine fracture).
